How does tourism affect food-related greenhouse gases?

A novel paper on climate change by Xingyu Zhao at Nanjing Forestry University reveals that tourism cut emissions by 620 million tons from 2001 to 2019! 

However, it warns that high meat consumption could lead to rising

One of the novel astrophysics papers this October explores the eclipsing binary system V415 Gem.

With an impressive 85% content novelty score, Bin Zhang at 
@GuizhouU
 reveals that the two stars touch but have different temperatures.

They also discovered a third star that

Check out our latest newsletter on the launch of novelty scores by DeSci Labs for over 250 million research articles on DeSci Publish!

One of the most novel papers on data science is from Anne Egelston at 
@TarletonState
!

This research dives into how international organisations work together for sustainable development and evaluates the effectiveness of these partnerships.

Check it out here:

Following the World Cancer Congress, 
@guardian
  reported on the need for stricter social media regulations to curb youth vaping.

A study from the Philippines found that 1 in 7 youths aged 13 to 15 are vaping, with a 99% novelty score.

Read more here: https://bit.ly/3U07THp

Exciting News! 

We’re thrilled to be shortlisted for Best Automation & Data Innovation at the Lab Awards 2024! 

This nomination reflects our commitment to pushing the boundaries of data-driven innovation.

 We’re proud to be recognised and look forward to the

Check out this exciting new paper on epidemiology by David P Rogers!

It aims to improve community warning systems by clarifying health crises and incorporating vulnerable groups into disaster response planning.

#Epidemiology #DisasterResponse

Check it out here:

Check out this innovative cell biology paper (77% novelty score) by Marco Garello et al. at @UniTorino!

The study uncovers harmful toxins produced by 10 types of Penicillium fungi, especially in foods like chestnuts, revealing potential health risks.

Read more here:

Check out this genetics paper with a 100% novelty score!

Authored by Vincent Seaman at the Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, this study investigates a cluster of polycythemia vera cases, a type of blood cancer, to uncover possible genetic causes.

Read it here:

Take a look at this clinical psychology paper that boasts a 100% content novelty score, showcasing groundbreaking insights!

Sharon Goldman at 
@HebrewU
 shows how older adults who frequently used communication technology during COVID-19 reported greater happiness and life

Thanks to 
@EPM_Magazine
 for covering our new novelty scores feature!

This tool offers an objective measure of novelty for over 250 million articles, including works by Nobel Prize winners

Check out this economics paper with a 100% novelty score, introducing breakthrough insights!

 This paper by Zhongua Zhu at 
@CUFE_1949
 the paper delves into how companies should invest their money when inflation is a concern.

Research can be hard navigating through paywalls, missing information, and relevance.

We’ve introduced novelty scores to measure innovation in 58M+ open-access papers and 200M paywalled articles – all searchable on http://desci.com!

Check it out! 

#OpenAccessScience

In September, the top radiotherapy physics paper, scoring 100% for novelty, comes from Satoshi Hasegawa at Utsunomiya University.

The study showcases high-speed femtosecond laser pulse modulation using holograms, opening doors to new industrial applications.

Check it out here:

Our new novelty score feature evaluates the innovation level of research papers compared to existing literature.

This enables effective comparisons of new research and its potential impact.

Click here to discover innovative research across various specialties!

September’s top cancer research paper, with a content   novelty score of 96%, comes from 
@CCSU_Official
  and Xinxia Zhu at 
@OHSUNews
 !

The study delves the miR-214 and Hedgehog pathways, which are linked to tumour growth in cancers like ovarian.

Discover more here:

Novelty scores measure how unique a research paper is compared to existing literature.

A high novelty score indicates groundbreaking studies that could lead to major breakthroughs.

Check out September’s most novel cancer research papers here: https://bit.ly/3TMCqsd

What can you find on our novelty scores page?

Novel work by institution
Prize winning works
Works by sector and field

Explore how your paper compares to 250 million papers! 

https://desci.com
An antitrust litigation has been filed against academic publishers by the same guys who recently led a $400 million no-poaching decision against Apple, Google, and other big techs.

Join DeSci Labs’ 
@evoladventurer
, part of an excellent panel of experts to discuss the success in harnessing decentralised science!

Scan the QR code to register for FREE for Saturday evening’s event at 14/F Three Exchange Square, Hong Kong.

Thanks to 
@LegalMung
  and

@Vita_DAO
 and VitaRNA using DeSci. We are excited to welcome you and your community on board!

#OpenScience #OpenAccess

Did you know we have our own LinkedIn newsletter?

 Subscribe today so you don’t miss a single edition of Making Science Accessible.

Subscribe on LinkedIn https://bit.ly/4dTg00a

#OpenScience #ScientificProgress #SciencePublishing

Read our latest article here: https://bit.ly/3Mp9NgJ

A scientific publishing landscape built on paid subscriptions and barriers to accessibility makes life difficult for young researchers who are entering the industry on their postgraduate degrees as it is harder for them to

This 
@guardian
 piece sums up the need for a new approach to scientific publishing.

https://bit.ly/3A5dRQ8

Hats off to Arash Abizadeh for making the bold move to leave their journal. But how do we overcome the lock-in strategy he’s trying to escape?

#OpenScience #Research

Follow our step-by-step guide on using DeSci Publish.

1. Upload your manuscript
2. Upload data and code files
3.  Claim badges
4. Receive submission package and DOI
5. Submit
Try it now at https://publish.desci.com

#OpenScience #Research #Publishing

Make sure you tune into hear our co-founder 
@PKoellinger
 discuss how we can shift power back towards researchers in this X-Space in just over two hours! 

#openscience

Make sure you tune into hear our co-founder 
@PKoellinger
 discuss how we can shift power back towards researchers in this X-Space in just over two hours! 

#openscience

Live on X-Spaces tomorrow...
We'll sit down with the most forward-thinking organizations in the scientific publishing industry.

Boost your research portfolio with DeSci Publish’s verifiable badges.

If your open data/code attestation claim gets validated by another user, your ORCID profile will automatically update, and provide evidence of authorship.

Find out more: https://publish.desci.com

#OpenScience

Exciting News! 

We’re part of FAIR2Adapt – a project that aims to build a more resilient, inclusive and knowledge-based society capable of efficiently tackling the challenges of climate change.

More updates to come soon!

#OpenScience #ClimateChange

It’s great to have the backing of someone like 
@mathemagicianMZ
 – who started his own start-up and is now leading his own company 
@block_science
.

Find out more: https://publish.desci.com

#OpenResearch #Transparency

Use DeSci Publish to make your work part of the official scientific record!

Publish allows you to create DOIs – meaning data, code and manuscripts you share will be indexed in CrossRef!

Find out more: https://publish.desci.com

#OpenScience

We’re in the midst of a replication crisis.

How do we fix it?

Our blog discusses the issues of skewed incentives and problematic journal business models, and looks at how we can change things for a better future.

Read it here https://bit.ly/DeSciBlog

If your latest scientific project:

Uses DeSci Publish
Follows best open science practices
Has an innovative research focus

Then you should enter 
@DesciFoundation
's fund to win a share of $10k.

To enter by August 14, visit:

Research shows that 2.82 million papers were indexed in 2022.

With so many papers in circulation, how can scientists gain recognition?

By making all parts of your research accessible, you increase trust in your work among editors currently swamped by AI generated manuscripts.

What grinds your gears about scientific publishing? 

Number one in our survey was peer-review work being unpaid, followed by it being hard for studies to be replicable.

Read more about our recent survey: https://bit.ly/3WdtlJv

#OpenScience #Research #Transparency

Have you listened to the latest episode of Future of Science podcast?

Listen to our episode with bioRxiv and medRxviv’s Richard Sever, here: https://open.spotify.com/episode/1e1BlQYlAoMrqTZ5f9aR2y…

#OpenScience #Research #PrePrints

We’re trapped amidst a culture of publish or perish.

How can we better value a researchers’ overall contribution to science?

Reply with your thoughts.

We are so pleased to help make things easier for researchers from leading institutions.

Such as Deniz Främke, Postdoctoral Fellow at Max Planck Institute for Human Development!

Find out more: https://publish.desci.com

Exciting News! 

Publish provides an intuitive publishing experience including:
Submission package builder improving publication chances
Track record of your methodology
DOIs for your research
Verifiable badges

https://publish.desci.com

When tracking scientific data, precision is paramount. Inability to do so hinders replication and trust in science.

We’re exploring how Web3 technology can create more accurate records with data integrity, reproducibility and traceability.

Find out more: https://bit.ly/Try-DeSci

Recent retractions outlined in an article from New Scientist highlights how physicists are grappling with the replication crisis.

We need a better way for researchers to share their data and code, so it’s clear how their conclusions have been reached.

https://bit.ly/DSC_Replication

What is your scientific publishing pet peeve?

We recently surveyed a group of scientists about their frustrations: unpaid peer review ranked #1.

Read the full results here: https://bit.ly/DeSci-PR

Pay-to-read has been integral to making science more accessible to readers, but it leaves many researchers paying high publication charges.

We’re on a mission to change the publishing business model for the better.

Subscribe to our blog for insights:

Should we pay researchers to spot errors in published scientific papers?

A recent 
@Nature
 article discusses whether science publications should pay researchers to find issues, but isn’t it too late at that point?

What do you think?

How was 
@BlockSplit
 2024?

We think this photo sums it up perfectly!

Thanks to the attendees, fellow presenters and organisers for a fantastic event filled with valuable conversations on the future of #ScientificResearch

It’s always great to see our co-founder Philipp in his natural habitat!

Didn’t catch his talk on our tools at 
@BlockSplit
?

Schedule a demo to see how DeSci Nodes is changing the game for scientific research https://bit.ly/Try-DeSci

@BlockSplit
 2024?

The platform ensures researchers can easily store and share aggregated research objects.

Contact our team for a demonstration https://bit.ly/Try-DeSci

How can scientific publishing be improved?

At the recent 
@BlockSplit
 event, our co-founder Philipp shared how DeSci Nodes can help accelerate scientific progress.

To see the tools for yourself, contact us for a demo https://bit.ly/Try-DeSci

My guess is this'll be hard &  unlikely to achieve the level of verification one would want in the time available. I'd like to see post-hoc checks by a constellation of third parties appended as badges as described here https://journals.plos.org/plosbiology/article?id=10.1371/journal.pbio.3002234… 2/n
Our nodes-lib integration library enables programmatic publications of data, code, and other content on the Nodes application. Here is a 2-minute demo:
Learn more in our blogpost:
Check out our new blog with articles about ARCs, the nodes-lib library, and the frustrations of researchers! For each post, 10 free collector NFTs can be minted :-)

Distributed computing needs a makeover. Fast. AI is accelerating far faster than we anticipated. Researchers are realizing that the traditional academic system hampers true progress. We need coordination mechanisms that align humans and machines in a cooperative manner, (1/19)
